history.content:
Sorry to hear things haven't been going well, and I hope they turn around for you soon!

I can't really give an answer from an employer's perspective, but at least w.r.t. all the professors I've interacted with, I think they would probably ask about it, and give you a chance to explain the situation. And the professors I've interacted with are very understanding and receptive of these things. Plus if you can use the stress relief from P/NP-ing 170 and channel it into working or pursuing something you enjoy more I think that'd really look cool!

And for employment, I don't think most companies require a transcript? (At least a lot of the applications I've done haven't included them I think). It's more the content of 170 that is likely to be more useful, and hopefully P/NP-ing it also allows you to focus more on picking up information than just grinding for a particular grade. (Also getting mean on the midterm is still pretty good -- as you probably know. But sounds like you have pretty high standards for yourself and that's cool as well!!) 

This is all just one fellow student's perspective though, and I'm sure there are many more out there... but I hope this helps!

Best of luck!

_____________________________________________________

The above answer is quite helpful so I believe it should be sufficient.
But honestly, "I normally score 1-1.5 standard deviations above the mean on exams in CS classes, but I got exactly the mean score on the first 170 midterm" doesn't really show you are struggling (unless you believe the only reason you got "mean" on the midterm is because of your mental health). The material in 170 is inherently challenging and many people don't do as well as they've been doing in other CS classes. Moreover, mean scores on tests (assuming you don't improve AT ALL in the remaining 170 tests, which is quite unlikely tbh) usually corresponds to a grade of B+ nowadays and that shouldn't bring down your GPA by a lot, especially since I assume you have closer to a 4 (considering you getting +1.5 SDs on tests). Now if you're really trying to keep your GPA in the high 3.9s for some reason (grad school probably?), then I personally think P/NP would show quite negatively to admission officers/professors.

Sorry to hear things haven't been going well, and I hope they turn around for you soon!

I can't really give an answer from an employer's perspective, but at least w.r.t. all the professors I've interacted with, I think they would probably ask about it, and give you a chance to explain the situation. And the professors I've interacted with are very understanding and receptive of these things. Plus if you can use the stress relief from P/NP-ing 170 and channel it into working or pursuing something you enjoy more I think that'd really look cool!

And for employment, I don't think most companies require a transcript? (At least a lot of the applications I've done haven't included them I think). It's more the content of 170 that is likely to be more useful, and hopefully P/NP-ing it also allows you to focus more on picking up information than just grinding for a particular grade. (Also getting mean on the midterm is still pretty good -- as you probably know. But sounds like you have pretty high standards for yourself and that's cool as well!!) 

This is all just one fellow student's perspective though, and I'm sure there are many more out there... but I hope this helps!

Best of luck!

children.subject:
I wrote the initial response in the student answer box but I would like to agree with the above anon! 

I think you're definitely still on track to get a pretty decent grade; I understand that you may be concerned about your GPA, but unless you have other outstanding concerns (scholarship, really pushing for a high GPA for grad school [but tbh I think you can get by without needing to have an extremely high GPA]) you might also want to consider sticking with taking the class for a grade, but focusing more on what you're actually learning and not stressing too much about the letter that comes out at the end.

Good luck regardless of your decision!

Sorry to hear that, but getting an average in 170 is pretty good!!! you could still get a good grade if you do well in the final I believe, and I don't think a single grade would affect jobs, research etc. I assume you have a pretty high GPA, so a non A score may be beneficial, because you just could not be perfect in everything, and it is better to know this fact early. Don't push yourself too hard. Based on my experience, I truly started enjoying all my math/cs classes after I got the first non-A score, since then, I didn't care too much about (not obssessed with) grades, cutoffs, exams, hkn tbp past exams... It sounds cliche, but 'chasing' good grades could not get us an "A" in life. Just P/NP if you feel really bad, health is more important! And do some useless, fun things~

Just a note: I think you can only P/NP 170 if you're LSCS. If you're EECS, the only way you can do that if (1) you use the late change of schedule, and (2) have already completed all of your degree requirements.

history.content: Hello, long story short I've been dealing with some mental health issues this semester as a result of pushing myself way too hard and am really struggling to keep up with all of my work. My number one source of stress right now is CS 170 because of the massive workload the class gives, which is made worse by the fact that I don't really enjoy the content of the class. I haven't been doing well in the class despite my efforts for the reasons I mentioned in the first sentence of this post, so I'm considering just changing my grading option to P/NP. I'm confident I can pass the class, I just don't want the low grade to drag down my GPA (i.e. I normally score 1-1.5 standard deviations above the mean on exams in CS classes, but I got exactly the mean score on the first 170 midterm). My question is, how bad would it look to prospective employers I want to work for or professors I am interested in doing research with if my transcript shows that I took CS 170 P/NP?
history.subject: How bad would it look if I P/NP'ed CS 170?
